title: 111_hr2069
content: The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" is also known as the Credit for New Motor Vehicle Purchases under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" allows a $3,000 credit for each qualified motor vehicle placed in service during the taxable year. No credit is allowed for vehicles with a fair market value exceeding $40,000. Additionally, 50 percent of the credit for qualified motor vehicles subject to depreciation can be claimed for business purposes. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" allows a $3,000 credit for each qualified motor vehicle placed in service during the taxable year, with a limit of 2 vehicles per taxpayer. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity for the credit. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall be treated as a personal credit, excluding vehicles subject to depreciation. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" allows a $3,000 credit for each qualified motor vehicle placed in service during the taxable year, with a limit of 2 vehicles per taxpayer. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall be treated as a personal credit, excluding vehicles subject to depreciation. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year shall not exceed the excess of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, over the sum of the credits allowable under subpart A and section 27 for the taxable year. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" provides a $3,000 credit for each qualified motor vehicle meeting specific criteria, including being made by a manufacturer in the US and having a gross vehicle weight rating of not more than 8,500 pounds. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" provides a $3,000 credit for qualified motor vehicles meeting specific criteria, including being made by a US manufacturer and having a gross vehicle weight rating of not more than 8,500 pounds. Special rules apply for reducing basis and avoiding double benefits for qualified vehicles used by tax-exempt entities. The "Credit for New Cars Act of 2009" provides a $3,000 credit for qualified motor vehicles meeting specific criteria. If a vehicle is not subject to a lease, the seller is treated as the taxpayer placing the vehicle in service if they disclose the allowable credit amount. No credit is allowed for property used outside the United States. The Secretary may issue regulations for recapture. The Secretary may recapture the credit for property no longer eligible. Taxpayers can elect not to take the credit for a vehicle. Vehicles must comply with Clean Air Act for credit eligibility. The new motor vehicle credit is subject to termination for vehicles placed in service after December 31, 2009. The credit is now part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. Conforming amendments have been made to ensure compliance with the Clean Air Act for credit eligibility. Section 30E(c) applies. Conforming amendments have been made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to include references to sections 30D and 30E. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include references to sections 30D and 30E, with specific changes made to sections 6501(m) and the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by section 30E apply to vehicles acquired after December 31, 2008. The amendment made by subsection (c)(1)(A) is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001.
